p.emph: In 1911, the Governor's Horse Guard, First Company became Troop B, Cavalry, of the National Guard. In 1917, it became part of the 101st Machine gun Battalion, 26th Division.

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, 1863-1880, muster rolls, 1803-1815, paid bills, 1897-1899, Treasurer's "skeleton reports", 1880-1893, orders, 1862-1871, deeds, leases, contracts on construction of armory, 1887-1889, receipts for new uniforms, etc., 1873, certified copy of Foot Guard Charter and other General Assembly acts, 1771 ff., and Groton celebration, 1826 and 1881.
Volumes A, C, and D

From Major Commandant george W. Tule and Major George A. Ford concerning the 200th Anniversary Celebration, September 29-October 2, 1971.

Lithographed copy with ornamental head and Jonathan Trumbull's signature of the General Assembly resolution of 1788 creating the company. The document carries the wrong date (May 1778) and Trumbull's signature is a copy as he died in 1785. Included are notes on provenance and a reduced sized photograph.

note.p: Photostat copies with accompanying documents are in the Catalogued Archives: 973.9 G741.

bioghist.p: When first formed, this unit was called a Battalion. Later it was called a Regiment. Also, at some point parts of this Regiment were transfered to the Second New York Cavalry.

arrangement.p: Lists by company by mostly identified only by Captain's name.

note.p: Note: the company identifications for the first three regiments of Connecticut Volunteers (three months) are confusing. Some companies are identified as "Rifle", some as "Infantry". Furthermore companies were given one identification, A, B, C, etc. by the State when the regiment was formed, but this designation was changed when the regiment was mustered into the U.S. forces. See the following volume to straighten this out, Record of Connecticut Men in the War of the Rebellion, 1861-1865, Part I. Many documents are identified only by the Captain's name.
